title: Is it wrong to eat plants?
intro: Plants don’t have brains or nerves, but according to some scientists, they can learn, solve problems, and even recognise other plants in their ‘family’. So, given the amazing things plants do, is it right to eat them? That’s what we talk about in this programme, and we teach you vocabulary along the way.
this_week_question: Which tropical plant is famous for trapping insects to eat?
a)    the corpse flower b)    the American skunk cabbage c)    the Venus fly trap
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: able to quickly notice and understand things
and even more; used to emphasise that what was said before was an understatement
when considered alone, without taking any other factors into account
general situation or circumstances in which something happens

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I’m Rob.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Many people these days choose not to eat meat, and for vegetarians, eating animals is wrong. But what about digging up a carrot, or picking apples from a tree? Is that wrong too?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I don’t think so, Neil. Plants aren’t alive in the same way as animals, are they? They can’t think or feel pain. And even vegetarians need to eat something . Fruit, vegetables, rice, beans – they all come from plants.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It’s true that plants don’t have brains or nerves, but according to some scientists, they’re much more than passive things rooted in the ground. Plants can learn and remember, they solve problems, and can even recognise other plants in their ‘family’. So, given the amazing things plants do, is it right to eat them? That’s what we’ll be discussing in this programme, and as usual we'll be learning some new useful vocabulary as well.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But first I have a question for you, Neil. Anyone who's seen cows grazing knows it’s usually animals that eat plants, but some plants have turned the evolutionary tables to eat animals instead. So, which tropical plant is famous for trapping insects to eat? Is it: a)    the corpse flower? b)    the American skunk cabbage? or c)    the Venus fly trap?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I think it’s c) the Venus fly trap.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, Neil. We’ll find out if that’s the right answer later in the programme. Plants have been on the planet for hundreds of millions of years longer than humans, and have used that time to evolve special skills. Here’s Professor Rick Karban, a biologist at the University of California, explaining more to James Wong, botanist and presenter of BBC Radio 4 programme, Is Eating Plants Wrong?

transcript.author: Prof. Richard Karban
transcript.text: Without eyes plants can perceive a lot of information about light, without noses plants can perceive chemical information, without ears plants can perceive sounds, and so we've come to realise that plants are very perceptive about what's going on in their environments.

transcript.author: James Wong
transcript.text: You could argue for example that plants can perceive most of the senses that humans can.

transcript.author: Prof. Richard Karban
transcript.text: I would agree with that and then some …

transcript.author: James Wong
transcript.text: What d’you mean, ‘ and then some’ ?

transcript.author: Richard Karban
transcript.text: Anyone who's had a dog knows that dogs have a much keener sense of smell than humans do, and we're now learning that plants are very responsive to chemicals in their environment.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Even without ears, eyes, or a nose, plants are very perceptive – they notice things around them. In fact, Professor Karban says that plants perceive as much as humans and then some - an idiom meaning ‘and even more’ which is used to emphasise that what you mentioned before was an understatement. For example: Bill Gates is rich and then some!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Like dogs, plants have a keen sense of smell, which they used to detect chemicals in the air. Here, keen means powerful and intense.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, so plants can ‘see’ light and ‘smell’ the air, but does that mean they’re intelligent?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Maybe so. Studies modelled on the famous Pavlov’s dog experiment, have trained pea seedlings to find the quickest route to light through a maze, and remember it – evidence of memory. In another experiment, potted plants were lined up with roots joining them like a chain of people holding hands. The plants talked to each other, passing along information about water and air temperature through their roots, like children playing a game where a message is passed on, in a whisper, through a chain of people, becoming distorted in the process. Distorted means changed from its original form.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: All this takes brain power, and there’s clearly evidence that plants might have some kind of intelligence. So, given all of this, is it wrong to eat them? That’s what James Wong asked, Michael Marder, professor of philosophy at the University of the Basque Country for his BBC Radio 4 programme, Is Eating Plants Wrong?

transcript.author: James Wong
transcript.text: Is it wrong to eat plants?

transcript.author: Prof Michael Marder
transcript.text: It is not in and of itself wrong to eat plants, but we have to do so while keeping in mind the context in which we're doing this. We have to first of all think about what kinds of plants we are eating, what are the parts of those plants? Are we in fact destroying the entire living being, or just taking certain of its parts such as fruits and leaves that are not essential to it that can actually fall off without doing harm to the whole organism?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Professor Marder says that eating plants is not wrong in and of itself – when considered alone, without taking anything else into account. But he thinks it’s important to remember the context – the situation or circumstances in which something happens. Picking an apple, for example, is okay because it doesn’t kill the tree itself which can go on to produce more fruit.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It seems plants really are clever – but do they know the answer to your question, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Ah yes, I asked you to name the famous insect-eating topical plant.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said it was the Venus fly trap.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Which was the correct answer. Well done, Neil. OK, let’s recap the vocabulary we’ve learned, starting with the adjective perceptive – quick to notice and understand things.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The idiom, and then some means ‘and even more’ and is used to show that something has been understated.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: A keen sense of smell, sight or hearing , is powerful and intense.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Distorted means changed from its original form.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: The phrase in and of itself means when considered alone, without taking anything else into account.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And finally, the context is the general situation in which something happens. Once again, our six minutes are up. Goodbye!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Goodbye!
